discharge_summary: problem: high-risk burkitt-like lymphoma stage iv infiltration mo diagnosis 2020 right neck mass nasopharyngeal renal lesions, cervical lymph node biopsy 05/22: morphological and immunohistochemical picture of b-cell lymphoma, with small, intermediate-sized cells and high proliferative index. immunohistochemistry: positivity for cd20, pax5, weak cd10, bcl6. negativity for cd34, tdt, bcl2, cmyc, ki67 of 95 100%. cd3 evidenced the population of reactive t lymphocytes. cmyc negativity rules out the diagnosis of burkitt's lymphoma. the present case may correspond to burkittlike lymphoma with 11q aberration nasopharyngeal mass biopsy 05/26: b lymphoma with high mitotic index cerebrospinal fluid puncture 06/05: no bmo infiltration 06/03/2020: diffusely infiltrated by b lymphoma with high mitotic index. cd19 / cd 20 / cd10 / bcl 6 if de mo 06/04: cd 19 / cd 20 / cd10 / cd 43 / cd 81 / lambda collection of material for semen cryopreservation 06/05/2020 ecog 0. admission: 13/08/2020, discharge: 08/21/2020, stay: 07 d 22 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma was admitted to the hospital for a second cycle of Rivac D1: 14/08/2020. On 08/16, D3 of the second Rivac, he had a fever peak of 38.1 °C, which lasted for about 1 hour. He reported nausea and had had 3 episodes of bowel movements with softer stools on the day in question. He also had a blood count on the day with 2,000 neutrophils, but already falling, with a tendency towards neutropenia. Given this, the condition was managed as febrile neutropenia, with a probable abdominal focus of infection. It was decided to start cefepime and metronidazole. He underwent a chest CT scan without changes, and a CT scan of the sinuses with evidence of content in the frontal sinus and mastoid. An endoscopic evaluation of the sinuses was performed by [organization], with no evidence of invasive fungal infection. remained on intravenous antibiotic therapy until 08/20, when antibiotic therapy was discussed with [organization], and it was decided to transition to oral clavulin ciprofloxacin. In addition to this, he underwent chemotherapy to date without other complications. He required a transfusion of 1 red blood cell concentrate on 08/19, without complications. Normal physical examination upon discharge. No procedures were performed. Diagnosis already established. 1. I provide folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet, to be taken on 09/01/20 to be taken 24 h after intrathecal chemotherapy 2. I prescribe amoxicillin clavulanate 875 125 mg and ciprofloxacin 500 mg, to be used every 12/12 h, until 8 am on 08/31 3. I prescribe filgrastim for use of 600 mg 2 ampoules in the morning and 300 mg 1 ampoule at night, via subcutaneous application, every day, until the follow-up appointment on 08/27 4. I prescribe prophylaxis: acyclovir 200 mg 2 tablets every 12/12 h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet every 12/12 h on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays omeprazole 20 mg 1 capsule on an empty stomach 5. I prescribe, for use in case of constipation and no bowel movement: lactulose syrup 15 ml every 8 hours, and bisacodyl 5 mg 1 tablet at night. 6. I prescribe ondansetron, in case of nausea or vomiting. 08/25 blood center transfusion room 08/27 outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 08/31 madit outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 09/15 [organization] safety follow-up appointment for clinical reevaluation and check PETCT scheduling counter 6 HC. Good.
question: Is this my right diagnosis? The short statement seems to be saying two different things.
answer: Her problem is an 'advanced Burkitt's lymphoma Stage IV'. In short, 'CMYC negative Burkitt's lymphoma' causes difficulty in identification, and this case may be related to '11q' abnormality associated with Burkitt's lymphoma.

question: ह्या फिलग्रिस्टिम मालियाचें नांव कितें?
answer: 27 ऑगस्टामेरेन दर दिसा नोकरेखातीर अर्ज करपाक तूं एक फिलोगोस्टिम आसा.

discharge_summary: problem: high-risk burkitt-like lymphoma stage iv infiltration mo diagnosis 2020 right neck mass nasopharyngeal renal lesions, cervical lymph node biopsy 05/22: morphological and immunohistochemical picture of b-cell lymphoma, with small, intermediate-sized cells and high proliferative index. immunohistochemistry: positivity for cd20, pax5, weak cd10, bcl6. negativity for cd34, tdt, bcl2, cmyc, ki67 of 95 100%. cd3 evidenced the population of reactive t lymphocytes. cmyc negativity rules out the diagnosis of burkitt's lymphoma. the present case may correspond to burkittlike lymphoma with 11q aberration nasopharyngeal mass biopsy 05/26: b lymphoma with high mitotic index cerebrospinal fluid puncture 06/05: no bmo infiltration 06/03/2020: diffusely infiltrated by b lymphoma with high mitotic index. cd19 / cd 20 / cd10 / bcl 6 if de mo 06/04: cd 19 / cd 20 / cd10 / cd 43 / cd 81 / lambda collection of material for semen cryopreservation 06/05/2020 ecog 0. admission: 13/08/2020, discharge: 08/21/2020, stay: 07 d 22 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma was admitted to the hospital for a second cycle of Rivac D1: 14/08/2020. On 08/16, D3 of the second Rivac, he had a fever peak of 38.1 °C, which lasted for about 1 hour. He reported nausea and had had 3 episodes of bowel movements with softer stools on the day in question. He also had a blood count on the day with 2,000 neutrophils, but already falling, with a tendency towards neutropenia. Given this, the condition was managed as febrile neutropenia, with a probable abdominal focus of infection. It was decided to start cefepime and metronidazole. He underwent a chest CT scan without changes, and a CT scan of the sinuses with evidence of content in the frontal sinus and mastoid. An endoscopic evaluation of the sinuses was performed by [organization], with no evidence of invasive fungal infection. remained on intravenous antibiotic therapy until 08/20, when antibiotic therapy was discussed with [organization], and it was decided to transition to oral clavulin ciprofloxacin. In addition to this, he underwent chemotherapy to date without other complications. He required a transfusion of 1 red blood cell concentrate on 08/19, without complications. Normal physical examination upon discharge. No procedures were performed. Diagnosis already established. 1. I provide folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet, to be taken on 09/01/20 to be taken 24 h after intrathecal chemotherapy 2. I prescribe amoxicillin clavulanate 875 125 mg and ciprofloxacin 500 mg, to be used every 12/12 h, until 8 am on 08/31 3. I prescribe filgrastim for use of 600 mg 2 ampoules in the morning and 300 mg 1 ampoule at night, via subcutaneous application, every day, until the follow-up appointment on 08/27 4. I prescribe prophylaxis: acyclovir 200 mg 2 tablets every 12/12 h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet every 12/12 h on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays omeprazole 20 mg 1 capsule on an empty stomach 5. I prescribe, for use in case of constipation and no bowel movement: lactulose syrup 15 ml every 8 hours, and bisacodyl 5 mg 1 tablet at night. 6. I prescribe ondansetron, in case of nausea or vomiting. 08/25 blood center transfusion room 08/27 outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 08/31 madit outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 09/15 [organization] safety follow-up appointment for clinical reevaluation and check PETCT scheduling counter 6 HC. Good.
question: What is the purpose of my entry from September 15th?
answer: 15 सप्टेंबर, तुजी सुरक्षा ठेव वैजकी तपासणी खातीर भरपाची आसा, आनी पी.ई.टी.सी.टी. स्कॅन थारायलां.

discharge_summary: admission: 10/06/2020, discharge: 11/20/2020, stay: 01 m 13 d 19 h, location: ward, payer: sus. discharge report patient [person], 54 years old, single, from [address], receives retirement benefit, admitted to the emergency unit of [organization] on 10/06 with dyspnea 8 days after admission, fever not measured and cough with greenish sputum. on 10/08, he presented respiratory failure, requiring orotracheal intubation and high oxygen concentrations pao2/fio2 ratio: 104, with neuromuscular blockade for ventilation for sara. On 10/9, due to oliguria in the last 24 hours, however, maintaining a positive fluid balance, he was transferred to the semi-intensive care unit without the use of vasoactive drugs due to the hypothesis of nephrotoxicity. On 10/10, vasoactive drugs were restarted due to poor peripheral perfusion. Neuromuscular blockade with cisatracurium was suspended. [person] developed abdominal distension, with suspension of the diet. On 10/14, an abdominal ultrasound was performed with no signs of ascites or gaseous distension. On 10/15, sedation was suspended. On the same day, [person] presented with a deviation of the fixed gaze to the right, being evaluated by neurology and, after a computed tomography scan of the skull and electroencephalogram, without new alterations that would justify the condition, vitamin B1 replacement was indicated. On 10/19, a thoracic ultrasound was performed, showing evidence of pleural effusion on the left, measuring approximately 3.3 cm. Diagnostic thoracentesis was performed, with negative transudate culture and bacilloscopy, but with positive TBTRM on 10/22. At the time, a case of ICC was discussed, and as [person] did not present a picture suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis upon admission, with no characteristic image, remaining afebrile throughout hospitalization, with progressive improvement of the pulmonary condition with Bactrim, in addition to 3 negative gastric lavage bacilloscopy samples in August of that year, it was decided not to isolate [person] and not to collect bacilloscopy again, since the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis was very unlikely. On 10/22, extubation was performed, without complications. On 10/23, [person] presented diarrhea, with liquid stools, no pathological products and no other systemic symptoms. On 10/25, he started a soft oral diet with good acceptance, and the nasogastric tube was removed and treatment for pleural tuberculosis was initiated by the attending medical team. On 10/26, [person] was admitted to a bed in the [organization] ward and, on 10/29, transferred to a bed in the [organization] ward, under the care of the infectious disease team. On 10/28, treatment for pneumocystosis with Bactrim D21/D21 was suspended and corticosteroid therapy was suspended, with Bactrim being resumed at a prophylactic dose for neurotoxoplasmosis and pneumocystosis. During hospitalization, [person] presented persistent thrombocytopenia while on prophylactic anticoagulation. Hematology assessed him and indicated the start of full-dose subcutaneous fondaparinoux 7.5 mg. On 11/3, with a platelet count above 150,000, dual anticoagulation with warfarin 5 mg/day was initiated. maintained until 11/08, with warfarin adjustment according to prothrombin time, due to anticoagulation for 4 weeks. In addition, [person] presented anemia probably secondary to azathioprine myelotoxicity and vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 replacement was started, 1 vial of 5000 mcg 1x per week. Upon admission to the [organization] ward, it was decided to suspend the RIP regimen due to an acute clinical laboratory picture not compatible with pulmonary or pleural tuberculosis. [person] presented infectious urinalysis culture positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, but as he remained asymptomatic and with good renal function, it was decided not to treat it, considering contamination. [person] is currently fit for hospital discharge, being on room air, with no signs of discomfort, hemodynamically stable, not using vasoactive drugs, and with good acceptance of oral diet, assisted only by the risk of bronchoaspiration, with international normalized ratio in the range of 2.9 with 5 mg of warfarin/day. Current problem 1. Nosocomial pneumonia? Recent admission to [organization] 08/14 09/25 Community-acquired pneumonia treated with clavulin, pcp Presumed hepatotoxicity due to bactrin Nosocomial pneumonia treated with cefepime 2. Pneumocystosis? 3. Normochromic macrocytic anemia to be clarified secondary to bactrim? Secondary to zidovudine? 4. Thrombocytopenia to be clarified Thrombocytopenia induced by prophylactic heparin? Tests 1. Transthoracic echocardiography 08/17: cardiac chambers with normal dimensions. left ventricular systolic performance and segmental mobility were normal. 2. abdominal ultrasound 8/17: ultrasound signs that may correspond to liver disease, with no evidence of suspicious focal lesions. absence of free intra-abdominal fluid. problem: 1. human immunodeficiency virus c3 diagnosed in 2004 8/17: cd4 135/cv: undetectable 2. neurotoxoplasmosis with motor sequelae in the right upper limb 3. anti hcv / hcv pcr negative 4. neurological disorder to be clarified wernicke's encephalopathy? psychiatric disorder to be clarified 5. chronic liver disease diagnosed in 2016 6. presumed chronic obstructive pulmonary disease medications in use risperidone 2 mg at night warfarin 5 mg/day until 12/01 discontinue after antiretroviral therapy: tenofovir 300 mg lamivudine 300 mg 1 tablet early darunavir 600 mg 1 tablet 12/12h ritonavir 100 mg 1 tablet 12/12h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet 12/12h pcp prophylaxis and neurotoxicity folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet/day. no changes.. programming we consider anemia secondary to probable myelotoxicity due to antiretroviral therapy AZT being replaced by tenofovir on 11/09. I maintain prophylaxis for PCP and neurotox with Bactrim, maintain folinic acid replacement 15 mg/day until follow-up appointment, decided to suspend vitamin B12 replacement, given 2 recent dosages with normal vitamin B12, maintain anticoagulation with warfarin started on 11/03 for 4 weeks until 12/01. follow-up appointment to the outpatient clinic, request tests for follow-up appointment. Good.
question: हांव हॉस्पिटलांत खंय आशिल्लो?
answer: 10 जून दिसा, स्वास घेवपाक त्रास जाल्ल्यान आनी खोंकली आयिल्ल्यान तुमकां आपत्कालीन विभागांत दाखल केलो. 10 ऑगस्ट दिसा, तुमचो स्वास बंद पडलो, आनी तुमकां एंडोट्रॅकियाल इंट्यूबेशन (श्वास घेवपाची नळी) गरजेची पडली.

question: The dog said his fever test was positive, but later they said it wasn't. I also have a fever.
answer: तुजे थुंकेंतले तपासणेचो अहवाल टी.बी. पॉझिटिव्ह आयलो. पूण, उपचार सुरू केलो आनी मागीर थांबयलें कारण तुजे 'क्लिनिकल लॅबोरेटरीचे निष्कर्ष फुफ्फुसाच्या वा प्लुरल क्षयरोगा कडेन सुसंगत नाशिल्ले,' आनी निदान 'खूबच अशक्य' मानलें.

question: म्हज्यान रगत नासतना वारफ्रायन वापरपाक जाय?
answer: हॉस्पिटलांत आसतना, तुमकां 'क्रॉनिक थ्रोम्बोसायटोसायटोसिस' (उणी प्लेटलेट संख्या) जालां अशें निदान जालें. तुमकां हेमॅटोलॉजी विभागांतल्यान संपर्क केलो, आनी निमाणें, तुमी वॉरफेरिन घेवपाक सुरवात केली. 11/03 सावन सुरू करून 12/01 मेरेन 4 सप्तकां वॉरफेरिन चालू दवरपाची येवजण आसा.

discharge_summary: high-risk burkitt-like lymphoma stage iv infiltration mo diagnosis 2020 right neck mass nasopharyngeal renal lesions, cervical lymph node biopsy 05/22: morphological and immunohistochemical picture of b-cell lymphoma, with small, intermediate-sized cells and high proliferative index. immunohistochemistry: positivity for cd20, pax5, weak cd10, bcl6. negativity for cd34, tdt, bcl2, cmyc, ki67 of 95 100%. cd3 evidenced the population of reactive t lymphocytes. cmyc negativity rules out the diagnosis of burkitt's lymphoma. the present case may correspond to burkittlike lymphoma with 11q aberration nasopharyngeal mass biopsy 05/26: b lymphoma with high mitotic index cerebrospinal fluid puncture 06/05: no bmo infiltration 06/03/2020: diffusely infiltrated by b lymphoma with high mitotic index. cd19 / cd 20 / cd10 / bcl 6 if de mo 06/04: cd 19 / cd 20 / cd10 / cd 43 / cd 81 / lambda collection of material for semen cryopreservation 06/05/2020 ecog 0. admission: 13/08/2020, discharge: 08/21/2020, stay: 07 d 22 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma was admitted to the hospital for a second cycle of Rivac D1: 14/08/2020. On 08/16, D3 of the second Rivac, he had a fever peak of 38.1 °C, which lasted for about 1 hour. He reported nausea and had had 3 episodes of bowel movements with softer stools on the day in question. He also had a blood count on the day with 2,000 neutrophils, but already falling, with a tendency towards neutropenia. Given this, the condition was managed as febrile neutropenia, with a probable abdominal focus of infection. It was decided to start cefepime and metronidazole. He underwent a chest CT scan without changes, and a CT scan of the sinuses with evidence of content in the frontal sinus and mastoid. An endoscopic evaluation of the sinuses was performed by [organization], with no evidence of invasive fungal infection. remained on intravenous antibiotic therapy until 08/20, when antibiotic therapy was discussed with [organization], and it was decided to transition to oral clavulin ciprofloxacin. In addition to this, he underwent chemotherapy to date without other complications. He required a transfusion of 1 red blood cell concentrate on 08/19, without complications. Normal physical examination upon discharge. No procedures were performed. Diagnosis already established. 1. I provide folinic acid 15 mg 1 tablet, to be taken on 09/01/20 to be taken 24 h after intrathecal chemotherapy 2. I prescribe amoxicillin clavulanate 875 125 mg and ciprofloxacin 500 mg, to be used every 12/12 h, until 8 am on 08/31 3. I prescribe filgrastim for use of 600 mg 2 ampoules in the morning and 300 mg 1 ampoule at night, via subcutaneous application, every day, until the follow-up appointment on 08/27 4. I prescribe prophylaxis: acyclovir 200 mg 2 tablets every 12/12 h sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim 400 80 mg 1 tablet every 12/12 h on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays omeprazole 20 mg 1 capsule on an empty stomach 5. I prescribe, for use in case of constipation and no bowel movement: lactulose syrup 15 ml every 8 hours, and bisacodyl 5 mg 1 tablet at night. 6. I prescribe ondansetron, in case of nausea or vomiting. 08/25 blood center transfusion room 08/27 outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 08/31 madit outside hematology daytime room 10 counter 6 HC 09/15 [organization] safety follow-up appointment for clinical reevaluation and check PETCT scheduling counter 6 HC. Good.

question: कितें दाखयता म्हाका सिटी स्कॅन? म्हाका कसलोय संसर्ग जाल्लो काय?
answer: रगत तपासणींत कसलोच बदल मेळूंक ना, आनी सीटी स्कॅनाचेर फ्रंटल सायनस आनी मॅस्टॉइड गळू दिसले. एंडोस्कोपिक तपासणींत आक्रमक बुरशीजन्य संसर्गाचो कसलोच पुरावो मेळूंक ना.

discharge_summary: 1. bloodstream infection associated with Schilley catheter in the right femoral vein sac 11/08 2. bacterial endocarditis associated with catheter echocardiogram 11/18: presence of vegetation in the mitral valve 3. pyogenic spondylodiscitis in l3/l4 11/05: low back pain, gait disturbance, computed tomography of the lumbosacral spine 11/12: findings suggestive of a fracture due to bone fragility of the vertebral body of l1, gas foci in the spinal canal at the level of l2l3 that may be related to an extruded disc herniation with degenerative disc disease, and an infectious or inflammatory process cannot be ruled out, lumbar magnetic resonance imaging 25/11/2020: infectious spondylodiscitis with anterior epidural abscess 4. left ileopsoas abscess, magnetic resonance imaging 25/10/2020: intramuscular collection in the ileopsoas left 15 x 2.1 x 1.8 cm with edema and adjacent post-contrast enhancement. admission: 11/08/2020, discharge: 01/02/2021, stay: 01 m 24 d 15 h, location: ward: ward payer: sus. [person] attends hemodialysis session with severe left lower back pain that had started 3 days ago, associated with asthenia, and altered gait. [person] who was accompanying him, denies fever, nausea, and vomiting. Denies other associated symptoms. catheter dressing in the right femoral vein was secreting. [person] evolved during hospitalization with a diagnosis of bloodstream infection by staphylococcus aureus mrsa, complicated by l2l4 spondylodiscitis, mitral valve infective endocarditis, and ileopsoas muscle abscess. Catheter removed on 11/08 and antibiotic therapy guided by vancomycin culture was started on 11/08. Abscess in psoas was not approached due to interposition of bowel loops in an attempt at percutaneous drainage by the {organization} on 12/02. Comparative radiological improvement was observed in axial lesions and conservative treatment was maintained regarding foci of infection identified during hospitalization. [person] remained afebrile with successively negative blood cultures. As a complication associated with immobility, he developed sacral pressure injury, treated with surgical debridement and local measures. Injury care guidelines were provided by the team. He evolved with the need for hemodialysis on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays due to arteriovenous fistula in the left upper limb, but local stenosis was noted. He is currently on renal replacement therapy. good general condition, pale 1/4, hydrated, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile to the touch and eupneic in room air. neurology: conscious and oriented in time, space and person. respiratory auscultation: bilateral vesicular breath sounds with discreet bibasilar crackles, no signs of respiratory distress. cardiac auscultation: irregular heart rhythm, with normal sound sounds, no murmurs. abdomen: protuberant, bowel sounds, normotensive, painless on superficial or deep palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation. warm and well perfused extremities. upper limbs: fistula in the left upper limb with present thrill. lower limbs: presence of discreet edema and anterior tibial ochre dermatitis. nuclear magnetic resonance 25/10/2020: intramuscular collection in the left ileopsoas 15 x 2.1 x 1.8 cm with edema and post-contrast enhancement adjacent cultures: catheter tip 11/08: vancomycin-sensitive staphylococcus aureus blood culture 11/08: staphylococcus aureus sg catheter 11/08 staphylococcus aureus blood culture 11/11: staphylococcus aureus oxa r in 2 samples blood culture 11/21: citrobacter koseri 1 sample staphylococcus aureus 1 sample blood culture 11/24: staphylococcus capitis blood culture 11/28: negative blood culture 12/01: negative blood culture 12/02: negative. attempted percutaneous abscess puncture on 12/02 not performed due to interposition of intestinal loops. nuclear magnetic resonance report of the pelvis performed on 12/16. agreed with [organization] for chronic patients to attend the hemodialysis room at [organization] on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, with transportation from the city of origin to the unit carried out by stretcher taxi {omitted}. therefore, we discharge the patient with the following pending issues: observations: administer 0.5 g of vancomycin after each scheduled hemodialysis session antibiotic therapy until 01/09/2021, completing 6 weeks after the last negative blood culture assessment of arteriovenous fistula: phlebography of arteriovenous fistula indicated assess fistulography by brachial to determine the site of stenosis and then perform phlebography or assess pre-procedure with ultrasound in the room. [person] placed on list. [organization] will contact you to schedule a treatment, as recorded in the note by the sacral pressure injury specialist team: [person]'s outpatient follow-up appointment on 16/01/2021 for pressure injury reassessment. Instructions for home care of the injury were provided. Cardiology follow-up for amyloidosis investigation: [person] missed a follow-up appointment appointment on 09/09, scheduled for 01/13 for motor rehabilitation. We are awaiting an appointment by the physiatry department at [organization] requested on 12/27. Check the nuclear magnetic resonance report of the pelvis from 12/16. question: कितलो सोपो आसा म्हजो कूड?
answer: तुजी कंबर दुखप खूब खर आशिल्लें. एम. आर. आय. स्कॅन तपासणींत स्पंदिलायटीस आनी फ्रंट एपिड्यूरल सूज दिसलां.

question: कितें, हांव वतना वखद घेवन वचूंक जाय?
answer: तुमी दर खेपे 0.5 ग्रॅम व्हॅनकोमायसीन घेवंक जाय, पूण हिमोडेलिसिस 01/09/2021 मेरेन थारायिल्लें आसूंक जाय. तुमी पयलीं व्हड काळाचें वखद लेगीत चालू दवरपाक जाय.

question: काय लाग काबार जाला?
answer: ताका जोर नाशिल्लो, आनी 28 नोव्हेंबरा सावन, एक सौम्य, सादी क्लिनिकल स्थिती तयार जाली. घायांनी सौम्य रेडिओलॉजिकल सुदारणा लेगीत दिसली.

question: आसा म्हाका डायलिसिस फिस्टुलांत कसलोय त्रास?
answer: वयल्या दाव्या हातान, धमनी आनी शिरा सकयल थळावो स्टेनोसिस मेळ्ळो. स्टेनोसिसाचें स्थान थारावपाक तपासणी गरजेची आसा.

answer: तुजी कार्डियोलॉजिस्टा कडेनची मीटिंग फकत 13/01 दिसा आसा, आनी तुजो प्रेशराच्या समस्ये खातीर फॉलो-अप 16/01/2021 दिसा आसा. तुमी मीटर रिहॅबिलिटेशना खातीरय अपॉइंटमेंट घेतलां.

[person] who was accompanying him, denies fever, nausea, and vomiting. Denies other associated symptoms. catheter dressing in the right femoral vein was secreting. [person] evolved during hospitalization with a diagnosis of bloodstream infection by staphylococcus aureus mrsa, complicated by l2l4 spondylodiscitis, mitral valve infective endocarditis, and ileopsoas muscle abscess. Catheter removed on 11/08 and antibiotic therapy guided by vancomycin culture was started on 11/08. Abscess in psoas was not approached due to interposition of bowel loops in an attempt at percutaneous drainage by the {organization} on 12/02. Comparative radiological improvement was observed in axial lesions and conservative treatment was maintained regarding foci of infection identified during hospitalization. [person] remained afebrile with successively negative blood cultures. As a complication associated with immobility, he developed sacral pressure injury, treated with surgical debridement and local measures. Injury care guidelines were provided by the team. He evolved with the need for hemodialysis on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays due to arteriovenous fistula in the left upper limb, but local stenosis was noted. He is currently on renal replacement therapy. good general condition, pale 1/4, hydrated, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile to the touch and eupneic in room air. neurology: conscious and oriented in time, space and person. respiratory auscultation: bilateral vesicular breath sounds with discreet bibasilar crackles, no signs of respiratory distress. cardiac auscultation: irregular heart rhythm, with normal sound sounds, no murmurs. abdomen: protuberant, bowel sounds, normotensive, painless on superficial or deep palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation. warm and well perfused extremities. upper limbs: fistula in the left upper limb with present thrill. lower limbs: presence of discreet edema and anterior tibial ochre dermatitis. nuclear magnetic resonance 25/10/2020: intramuscular collection in the left ileopsoas 15 x 2.1 x 1.8 cm with edema and post-contrast enhancement adjacent cultures: catheter tip 11/08: vancomycin-sensitive staphylococcus aureus blood culture 11/08: staphylococcus aureus sg catheter 11/08 staphylococcus aureus blood culture 11/11: staphylococcus aureus oxa r in 2 samples blood culture 11/21: citrobacter koseri 1 sample staphylococcus aureus 1 sample blood culture 11/24: staphylococcus capitis blood culture 11/28: negative blood culture 12/01: negative blood culture 12/02: negative. attempted percutaneous abscess puncture on 12/02 not performed due to interposition of intestinal loops. nuclear magnetic resonance report of the pelvis performed on 12/16. agreed with [organization] for chronic patients to attend the hemodialysis room at [organization] on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, with transportation from the city of origin to the unit carried out by stretcher taxi {omitted}. therefore, we discharge the patient with the following pending issues: observations: administer 0.5 g of vancomycin after each scheduled hemodialysis session antibiotic therapy until 01/09/2021, completing 6 weeks after the last negative blood culture assessment of arteriovenous fistula: phlebography of arteriovenous fistula indicated assess fistulography by brachial to determine the site of stenosis and then perform phlebography or assess pre-procedure with ultrasound in the room. [person] placed on list. [organization] will contact you to schedule a treatment, as recorded in the note by the sacral pressure injury specialist team: [person]'s outpatient follow-up appointment on 16/01/2021 for pressure injury reassessment. Instructions for home care of the injury were provided. Cardiology follow-up for amyloidosis investigation: [person] missed a follow-up appointment appointment on 09/09, scheduled for 01/13 for motor rehabilitation. We are awaiting an appointment by the physiatry department at [organization] requested on 12/27. Check the nuclear magnetic resonance report of the pelvis from 12/16. Previous chronic medications were maintained. Dialysis room Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays. Amyloidosis cardiology outpatient clinic 01/13. Pressure injury surgery outpatient clinic 01/16.
question: कितें तरेन म्हजो कॅटरर भायर सरलो?

question: म्हज्या काळजाचो स्कॅन कसो आसा?
answer: 18 नोव्हेंबराक, एका इकोकार्डियोग्रामान बॅक्टेरियाच्या एंडोकार्डायटिसाक जुळपी पर्क्यूटेनियस मायट्रल वाल्व्ह स्टॅनोसिस दाखयलो.

discharge_summary: 1 decompensated ic bc profile? decompensated pulmonary hypertension? liver injury? chronic liver disease? awaiting transthoracic echocardiography requested on 08/11 hypervolemia with transudate-type pleural effusion ascites edema lower limbs, on electrocardiogram: axis deviated to the right, signs of right atrial overload, inactive area on lateral wall. on tomography protocol pulmonary thromboembolism: dilated right atrium and ventricle, reflux of contrast into vena cava. blood gases: chronic co2 retention pattern normal bnp for age. hypoalbuminemia thrombocytopenia tgo tgp moderate volume ascites 2 perineal and lower limb cellulitis ruled out fournier by surgical team 08/11 3 pneumonia associated with mechanical ventilation worsening of secretion ventilatory worsening fever escalated antibiotic therapy for meropenem vancomycin on 08/16 and maintained metronidazole ruled out coronavirus. Negative pcr on 08/17, x-ray with right pleural effusion. Underwent diagnostic and relief thoracentesis on 08/18. 800 ml of serohematic-colored fluid was removed; transudate 4; acute kidney injury; baseline creatinine i code; admission: 0.98; clcr: 88 ml/min; kinetic 08/18: 48 ml/min; etiology: nta secondary to sepsis? hyperna hyperk; increased creatine phosphokinase; 5; atrial fibrillation with high ventricular response secondary to septic shock and fever 40º / lidocaine? amiodarone attack started 300 mg 300 mg and maintenance 900 mg/day on 08/18; cumulative dose of amiodarone on 08/19: 1.5g. admission: 08/11/2020, discharge: 08/20/2020, stay: 09 d 02 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] with a history of productive cough with whitish secretion, edema in the lower limbs, and dyspnea on moderate exertion for approximately 34 months, evolving with progressive worsening of dyspnea on mild exertion and a decline in general condition for approximately 2 weeks associated with odynophagia. 1 week ago [person] began to experience edema, hyperemia, heat, and pain in the genital region extending to the lower abdomen. He was taken to the emergency care unit and started on ceftriaxone 2 g/day d1 08/06 and later referred to [organization], where he was intubated due to acute respiratory failure. He was transferred to {organization} via advanced life support ambulance, intubated, hemodynamically stable, using dobutamine 20 ml/h and sedative and analgesia with fentanyl, midazolam and atracurium. No history of fever, rhinorrhea, sneezing, fever or other complaints. Serious general condition, flushed, hydrated, acyanotic, anicteric, feverish RAS4 pupils isomiotic respiratory auscultation vesicular breath sounds, reduced globally, with crackles in bases cardiac auscultation: 2 arrhythmic and normophonetic sounds in 2t without murmurs globular abdomen, normal bowel sounds, normotensive presence of sacral pressure injury. Heat in lower limbs legs bilaterally associated with edema. no signs of deep vein thrombosis genitalia with edema in penis and scrotum, associated with hyperemia and ulcer of approximately 1.5 cm in the foreskin of the bottom pustular lesion on the back, scaly cold and poorly perfused extremities. no surgeries performed. no pending exams. [person] evolved to death. discharged death.

question: कितें आसा म्हज्या नाडयेंत कसलोय त्रास?
answer: ताच्या क्ष-किरणांत 'मेकॅनिकल व्हेंटिलेशना कडेन संबंदीत निमोनिया' आनी 'उजव्या वटेन प्लुरल इफ्यूजन' दिसलें. ताका स्वास घेवपाक त्रास जातालो आनी दर एका स्वासाच्या शेवटाक 'घोरघोर आवाज' येतालो.

discharge_summary: coronavirus . admission: 2020-03-15, discharge: 2020-05-11, stay: 01 m 25 d 17 h, location: ward, payer: sus. id: [person], 59 years old, from [address] patient admitted on 2020-03-15 to the emergency unit of [organization] due to severe acute respiratory syndrome caused by coronavirus. patient in need of orotracheal intubation since 2020-03-17 with progression to tracheostomy on 2020-04-08. evolved with improvement in respiratory parameters being decannulated on 2020-05-08, remaining without tracheostomy, without respiratory discomfort, only with occlusive dressing. presented several complications during hospitalization, such as: 1 low-embolic load pulmonary thromboembolism, examination described below; 2 pulmonary septic shock with carbapenem-sensitive Acinetobacter baumannii, being treated with meropnem and polymyxin for 10 days and subsequently using tigecycline for 14 days, with improvement in the condition; 3 acute kidney injury, code 3, without the need for dialysis with subsequent reversal; 4 primary bloodstream infection secondary to Burkholderia cepacia, sensitive to ceftazidime and Bactrim. evolved with rehabilitation with motor and respiratory physiotherapy, with good tolerance and improved functionality during hospitalization. [person] without the need for oxygen therapy for more than 48 hours, with the need to consolidate treatment for bloodstream infection with oral Bactrim. opted for hospital discharge after a long period of hospitalization with improvement in the coronavirus condition and hospital complications. described below is the schedule for ending treatment for [person] after discharge. good general condition, pale 2/4, hydrated, oriented in time and space, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, eupneic heart rate: 70 oxygen saturation: 98% in room air cardiac auscultation: heart rhythm in normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, normal heart sounds, preserved capillary refill time, absence of jugular distension at 90º respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds present, no adventitious sounds, absence of use of accessory respiratory muscles abdomen: flaccid, painless, bowel sounds present and normal, tympanic to percussion, no palpable masses or palpable visceromegaly extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, well perfused extremities, absence of edema in the lower limbs, absence of signs of deep vein thrombosis neurology: Glasgow Coma Scale 15, presence of tremor postural in upper limbs. coronavirus pulmonary thromboembolism. schedule: anticoagulation for 6 months counting the start of treatment from 03/31/2020 ending on 09/31/2020 at the moment there is a need to use rivaroxaban 15 mg 12/12 h for another 7 days after discharge and subsequently use of a dose of rivaroxaban 20 mg/day until 05/07/2020. end of treatment for bloodstream infection with bactrin 2 tablets 8/8 hours for another 5 days after hospital discharge requested maintenance of respiratory and motor physiotherapy in [person's] city of origin. hospitalization exams: chest CT Angiography (CTA) 03/31: acute pulmonary thromboembolism with low embolic burden, without cor pulmonale. opacities compatible with coronavirus, severe involvement 50 - 75% with a component of organizing pneumonia and fibroreaction. cardiomegaly. Transthoracic echocardiography 07/05: ejection fraction 57%, mild dilation of the left atrium, preserved systolic performance of the right and left ventricles, without images suggestive of vegetation. discharge with follow-up in primary care. good conditions for hospital discharge.
question: हांव हॉस्पिटलांत खंय आशिल्लो?
answer: तुका 15 मार्च 2020 दिसा, कोरोनाच्या संसर्गाचीं गंभीर स्वास घेवपाचीं लक्षणां आशिल्ल्यान हॉस्पिटलांत दाखल केल्लो आनी हॉस्पिटलांत खूब तेंप (1 म्हयनो आनी 25 दीस) रावलो.

question: कितें जालें? म्हाका ट्यूब ना?
answer: He needed 'orothoric duct intubation' (tube to breathe) from 17 March 2020. This was converted to 'tracheostomy' on 8 April 2020. His body recovered and his 'tracheostomy' was 'dechlorinated' (tube to breathe removed) on 8 May 2020.

question: खंयच्यो समस्या आशिल्ल्यो म्हाका कोरोना वायरस भायर?
answer: ताका गंभीर भलायकी समस्यां खातीर हॉस्पिटलांत दाखल केलो: 1) तीव्र एम्बोलिक पल्मोनरी एम्बोलिझम, 2) पल्मोनरी सेप्टिक शॉक, 3) तीव्र मुत्रपिंड निकामी जावप, आनी 4) प्राथमिक धमनी संसर्ग.

[person] without the need for oxygen therapy for more than 48 hours, with the need to consolidate treatment for bloodstream infection with oral Bactrim. opted for hospital discharge after a long period of hospitalization with improvement in the coronavirus condition and hospital complications. described below is the schedule for ending treatment for [person] after discharge. good general condition, pale 2/4, hydrated, oriented in time and space, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, eupneic heart rate: 70 oxygen saturation: 98% in room air cardiac auscultation: heart rhythm in normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, normal heart sounds, preserved capillary refill time, absence of jugular distension at 90º respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds present, no adventitious sounds, absence of use of accessory respiratory muscles abdomen: flaccid, painless, bowel sounds present and normal, tympanic to percussion, no palpable masses or palpable visceromegaly extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, well perfused extremities, absence of edema in the lower limbs, absence of signs of deep vein thrombosis neurology: Glasgow Coma Scale 15, presence of tremor postural in upper limbs. coronavirus pulmonary thromboembolism. schedule: anticoagulation for 6 months counting the start of treatment from 03/31/2020 ending on 09/31/2020 at the moment there is a need to use rivaroxaban 15 mg 12/12 h for another 7 days after discharge and subsequently use of a dose of rivaroxaban 20 mg/day until 05/07/2020. end of treatment for bloodstream infection with bactrin 2 tablets 8/8 hours for another 5 days after hospital discharge requested maintenance of respiratory and motor physiotherapy in [person's] city of origin. hospitalization exams: chest CT Angiography (CTA) 03/31: acute pulmonary thromboembolism with low embolic burden, without cor pulmonale. opacities compatible with coronavirus, severe involvement 50 - 75% with a component of organizing pneumonia and fibroreaction. cardiomegaly. Transthoracic echocardiography 07/05: ejection fraction 57%, mild dilation of the left atrium, preserved systolic performance of the right and left ventricles, without images suggestive of vegetation. discharge with follow-up in primary care. good conditions for hospital discharge.

discharge_summary: admission: 05/28/2020, discharge: 06/06/2020, stay: 09 d 04 h, location: ward, payer: sus. identification: [person], 80 years old, from [address], social worker, retired, married. problem: 1 sepsis of pulmonary focus treated with ceftriaxone d10 clarithromycin d8 pulmonary focus: productive cough flu-like symptoms fever dyspnea desaturation 6 days ago acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creat 2.14 / basal 0.68 discharged from nephrology on 06/05. hypotension requiring norepinephrine. 2 atrial fibrillation with high ventricular response 05/28 reversed amiodarone chads2vas 4. 3 urinary tract infection candida treated with fluconazole. History of current illness: Patient with previous chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, under treatment with anoro umeclidino vilanterol, with a history of smoking, discontinued in 1988 53 pack-years. Reports that 6 days ago he started having a productive cough, associated with runny nose, nasal obstruction and shortness of breath, as well as a fever of 38 ºC in the first 3 days of symptoms. 3 days ago, he had an appointment with a pulmonologist, and was started on oseltamivir every 12 hours, but for the past 1 day he has been developing worsening shortness of breath, ventilatory-dependent pain in the back and lung bases, as well as a decline in general condition. Reports having taken tests for coronavirus and influenza, both negative. Denies gastrointestinal and genitourinary complaints. No other complaints. Personal history: 1. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (IPD)? Aspiration?? Spirometry 2019: obstruction with FEV1 31.59%, FVC 63.9%, no response to bronchodilator. Chest computed tomography 2021: emphysema, reticular infiltrate without honeycombing in the right base. Aspiration? 2. Systemic arterial hypertension 3. Diabetes mellitus 4. Hypothyroidism 5. Depressive disorder under current treatment. 6. Hearing impairment under treatment with a hearing aid. Continuous-use medications: Anoro, Metformin 1000 mg/day, Dapagliflozin 10 mg, Escitalopram 10 mg, Puran T 125 mcg, Rosuvastatin 5 mg, Calcium carbonate 1000 mg/day, Vit D3 1000 IU/day. Allergies: Denies. Surgeries: Denies. habits and addictions: denies alcoholism, smoking 52 pack-years; quit in 1988. antibiotic therapy ceftriaxone 1g 12/12h 05/28 06/06 clarithromycin 500 mg 12/12h 05/28 05/06 fluconazole 05/31 06/06. tests: transthoracic echocardiography 05/30/2020: mild left atrial dilation. concentric left ventricular remodeling, preserved systolic performance of the ventricles. normal left ventricular segmental mobility. mild mac mitral annular calcification. mild mitral and ai. clinical evolution [organization] finds [person] in a ward bed accompanied by [person]. hemodynamically stable, using a central venous catheter, no vasoactive drugs, and an indwelling urinary catheter. [person] reports improvement in respiratory condition, with reduction in fatigue and inspiratory pain and improvement in cough in appearance and volume, but reports that dyspnea persists with minimal effort such as taking a bath. Reports regular use of alenia, without use of supplemental oxygen, eupneic in room air, presents improvement in respiratory pattern. Reports anal pain, with presence of prolapsed hemorrhoid. Reports daily bowel movements, of liquid pasty consistency, without pain or effort. Reports bedsore in gluteal region without pain symptoms, reported by nursing and {person}. Discussed during visit with [person]: [person] with pneumococcus intermediate to ceftriaxone, however, given clinical and laboratory improvement, weaning from oxygen, maintaining cough, improving, we recommend hospital discharge. I keep [person] aware that in the event of further clinical worsening, he should seek emergency unit for reevaluation. [person] did not present recurrence of atrial fibrillation with high ventricular response; however, due to CHADs2 of 4, with a high risk of recurrence, seen in transthoracic echocardiography with atrial enlargement, we maintained rhythm control with amiodarone 200 mg 12/12h and started anticoagulation with rivaroxaban 20 mg/day. In addition, during hospitalization, he presented worsening of hemorrhoidal disease, now prolapsed, on local conservative therapy. question: म्हाका हॉस्पिटलांत भरती केल्लो काय?
answer: ताका "न्युमोनिटिस" (पुल्मांवांची सूज) जाल्ली. ताका "उत्पादक खोंकली, फ्लू सारकीं लक्षणां, जोर, स्वास घेवपाक त्रास आनी 6 दीस स्वास घेवपाक त्रास जालो".

question: म्हजो दाळो इबाडला काय कितें?
answer: तुमी 'गंभीर मुत्रपिंडाच्या जखमा kdigo 3' आशिल्ले. तुमी '06/05' सावन नेफ्रोलिनान डिस्चार्ज जाले, आनी डिस्चार्ज जातना तुमचें 'मुत्रपिंडाचें कार्य सुदारलें'.

question: म्हज्या काळजाक कितें जालें?
answer: तुमचो 28 मे दिसाचो 'उजव्या मेंदवाच्या उजव्या भागाचो चड प्रतिक्रियाशीलपणा' 'असामान्य' आशिल्लो. तुमचो इकोकार्डियोग्राफी 'उजव्या मेंदवाच्या उजव्या भागाचो थोडो प्रसार' दाखयता.

discharge_summary: 1 human immunodeficiency virus c3 human immunodeficiency virus recent diagnosis october 2020 weight loss and asthenia for two months cd4 18, viral load: 1,153,464 2 progressive dyspnea presumed pneumocystosis diffuse bilateral interstitial pulmonary infiltrate evolved with respiratory failure and need for supplemental oxygen noninvasive ventilation started on 10/15 bactrim 10/15 11/05 pulmonary cytomegalovirus? ganciclovir started on 10/22 treatment of community-acquired pneumonia with clarithomycin 10/15 10/20 and ceftriaxone 10/14 10/25 due to lack of clinical improvement and increasing needs for 02: tazocim started on 10/25 escalated to meropenem, polymyxin b and vancomycin hemodynamic worsening and tracheal aspirate with klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase intubated on 10/29 pulmonary tuberculosis tbtrm of bronchial lavage 11/03: positive tbtrm traces and previous negative sputum smears started ripe on 11/05 3 candidemia blood culture 10/28: candida orthopsilosis hemodynamic worsening 4 acute heart failure? secondary to myocarditis? secondary to taktosubo? 5 arrhythmia on 11/04 amiodarone impregnation on 11/04 900 mg/24h modified to 300 mg 8x8 h on 11/05 modified to 200 mg 8x8 h enteral on 11/06 6 frontal headache, without focal signs or new deficit, also two months ago 7 treated oral candidiasis 8 hyponatremia of etiology to be clarified siadh? 9 refractory septic shock pulmonary focus? catheter?. admission: 10/15/2020, discharge: 11/23/2020, stay: 01 m 07 d 22 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person] with a recent diagnosis of human immunodeficiency virus, was admitted to [organization] on 10/15 complaining of dyspnea, fatigue, fever, and cough. He began treatment for pneumocystosis and with clarithromycin and ceftriaxone for pneumonia. On 10/16, he was referred to [organization], where he continued to worsen his respiratory condition, having started treatment with ganciclovir for cytomegalovirus and with a new need for antimicrobial escalation. Even so, [person] evolved with worsening, being referred to the intensive care unit on 10/28. On 10/29, [person] developed hypotension and respiratory failure, having undergone orotracheal intubation since then. On 11/04, he presented tachyarrhythmia, and impregnation with amiodarone was started, and RIP was started due to the presence of TBTRM in the bronchial lavage with positive traces of tuberculosis. [person] continued to use vasoactive drugs, having shown no improvement even after new antimicrobial escalations and continued to present progressive clinical worsening, beginning to require hemodialysis. on 11/20 [person] began to present significant worsening of hemodynamic shock, having evolved with the need for vasoactive drugs at maximum doses, not even having tolerated the first hemodialysis session that would be performed on 11/21. despite the use of vasoactive drugs at maximum doses, [person] evolved with progressive hypotension, until on 11/23 he evolved to death. absence of cardiac electrical activity on monitor absence of pulse curve in invasive blood pressure absence of respiratory incursions absent central pulses absence of response to painful stimulus. absent corneopalpebral and photomotor reflexes. absence of cardiac electrical activity on monitor absence of pulse curve in invasive blood pressure absence of respiratory incursions absent central pulses absence of response to painful stimulus. absent corneopalpebral and photomotor reflexes. coronavirus test 10/18: negative tbtrm 11/03: traces. coronavirus test 10/18: negative tbtrm 11/03: traces. no surgeries or procedures were performed. no pending tests. no therapeutic plan or education to be carried out. [person] evolved to death. confirmed death at {omitted}.

discharge_summary: admission: 12/11/2020, discharge: 01/23/2021, stay: 01 m 11 d 10 h, location: ward, payer: sus [person], 28 years old, from [address] 12/14 weight: 102 kg height: 162 cm. problem: 1 Status epilepticus secondary to pulmonary infection Phenytoin attack performed and maintenance dose of PHT increased Pb dosage maintained Dosage of other drugs LTG, TPM and CLB 2 Sepsis pulmonary focus 3 Deep vein thrombosis Right lower limb Full dose of enoxaparin started on 12/23 4 Pseudomembranous colitis Metronidazole started 12/30 01/10 5 Adrenal insufficiency secondary to sepsis Hydrocortisone 50 mg every 12h started on 12/31 Weaning started on 01/10 Previous functionality Oral diet Walked without assistance Dependent for some instrumental activities of daily living Bathing, physiological eliminations. Tests: Electroencephalogram 12/12: Mild to moderate disorganization of baseline activity due to increased slow wave content in the theta and delta bands, but with the presence of normal sleep graphoelements. There was no clinical or electrographic reactivity to nociceptive stimulation. b Record of electrographic seizures of variable duration (4 to 9 seconds), characterized by rhythmic activity in the beta range, evolving to alpha and theta ranges, associated with spike-type epileptiform paroxysms, with generalized projection, without associated clinical phenomena. There was a record of a seizure with rhythmic evolution to the delta range and of longer duration (18 seconds). Rare spike-type paroxysms were recorded, occurring isolatedly in the left frontocentral region. Clinical correlation: The findings are consistent with focal epilepsy with electrographic seizures, but do not characterize status epilepticus. electroencephalogram 12/19: marked symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to persistent rhythmic, semi-rhythmic bifrontal slowing in the delta band, at approximately 1.5 Hz, of medium amplitude, only temporarily mitigated by nociceptive stimulation; furthermore, lack and poor definition of physiological graphoelements of sleep. Upon nociceptive stimulation, there is also a triggering of generalized rhythmic epileptiform activity in the beta band, of low voltage, which evolves into an outbreak of frank epileptiform paroxysms of the spike type followed by a slow wave, also of diffuse expression, and with bifrontal accentuation of such stimulus-induced discharges, suppression of the clinical tracing follows; [person] presents only with painful facies. b Occasionally, associated with the slow waves described above, bisynchronous epileptiform paroxysms of the sharp wave type are observed, involving the anterior regions of the scalp. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with severe diffuse encephalopathy of a nonspecific nature, associated with focal and generalized interictal epileptogenesis, the latter being stimulus-induced. Electroencephalogram 12/22: a moderate symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to an increase in the content of slow waves in the theta and delta bands, in addition to a lack and poor definition of the physiological graphoelements of sleep. However, good electroencephalographic reactivity is noted in response to nociceptive stimuli, with an association with a dominant posterior rhythmic outline in the alpha band. b bursts of generalized rhythmic delta activity (grda) with bifrontal accentuation, occurring intermittently throughout the tracing during sleep, consisting of stereotyped waves in the 2.0 to 2.5 Hz band. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with moderate diffuse encephalopathy, of a nonspecific nature in relation to the previous tracing; significant improvement is noted, with mitigation of grda and suppression of stimulus-induced generalized epileptogenesis. electroencephalogram 02/01: slight symmetrical disorganization of the baseline activity due to the slowing of the dominant posterior rhythm of wakefulness, recorded at a frequency of up to 6.5 Hz, however with the presence of typical physiological graphoelements of sleep. b recording of epileptiform paroxysms of the spike and sharp wave type, with generalized projection, with anterior accentuation, occurring in rhythmic bursts of short duration of 3 to 4 seconds. the paroxysms are followed by delta waves and, occasionally, rhythmic activity in the beta range of short duration of less than 1 second, which also occurred preceding the bursts of paroxysms, as well as in an isolated episode during drowsiness. c outbreaks of generalized delta activity, with bifrontal accentuation, the same projections as the paroxysms, also occurring exclusively during sleep. note: [person] presented stereotyped cephalic lateralization and oromandibular movements during wakefulness, however, without electrographic correlation with ictal patterns. conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. the findings are compatible with diffuse encephalopathy and generalized epilepsy. computed tomography of the skull 11/12: no relevant alterations; computed tomography of the chest 11/12: no signs of an infectious process; cerebrospinal fluid 13/12: 1 cell; 0 red blood cells; glucose: 96; protein: non-reactive; chloride: 125; lactate: 1.91; transthoracic echocardiography 23/12: no signs of vegetation. no other alterations. cultures: tracheal aspirate: 12/27: enterobacter cloacae complex sensitive to meropenem 12/19: negative 12/12: staphylococcus aureus oxas resistant to clindamycin 01/07: staphylococcus epidermididis oxar blood culture: 12/27: negative so far 12/19: staphylococcus hominis 12/13: negative 01/07: 01/16: pseudomonas aeroginosas sensitive to ciprofloxacin, cephalosporin and aminoglycoside urine culture: 12/27: negative 01/07: negative venous catheter: 12/27: negative 12/19: corynebacterium sensitive to vancomycin and teicoplanin 01/09: staphylococcus epidermidis oxar cerebrospinal fluid: 12/13: micrococcus sp antibiotic therapy: current: ceftazidime d0 01/19 pseudomonas bloodstream infection. AEDC follow-up appointments: 02/02 schedule to complete antibiotic therapy directed at pseudomonas bloodstream infection: using ceftazidime d3, maintain for 7-10 days: currently clinically stable, cpr falling, last 2.5 AEDC: 02/02/22 maintain current antiepileptic drugs until follow-up appointment: phenytoin 100 mg 12/12h phenobarbital 100 mg 12/12h topiramate 100 100 200 clobazam 20 mg 8/8h lamotrigine 100 100 200 I renew prescriptions from [organization] regarding deep vein thrombosis: I prescribe rivaroxaban 20 mg/d, I provide a prescription for 6 months. I request follow-up in the network. Follow-up by physiotherapy at the CER: difficulty walking, associated with equine feet. Wheelchair, bath and diaper report: already delivered. Treatment for scabies with ivermectin was carried out on 01/17, repeat in 7 days. Regular general condition, acyanotic, anicteric, hydrated, afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in 2t, normal sound sounds, no audible murmurs. Respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds in both hemithorax, no adventitious sounds. Globular abdomen, bowel sounds, depressed and no signs of defense. Warm extremities, capillary refill time less than 3s, free calves Glasgow 14, isochoric and photoreactive pupils, no pupillary hippus, no stigmata of crisis. Can raise all 4 limbs and hold them against gravity. Understands and obeys commands. Equine feet bilaterally.
question: कोणाकूय खऱ्या समस्येची म्हाका हॉस्पिटलांत  सामनो करचो पडलो काय?
answer: Specifically, your risks include: 1. Inflammatory bowel disease, 2. Inflammatory asthma, 3. Thrombosis of the first deep vein of the right leg, 4. Pseudomembranous colitis, and 5. Adrenal insufficiency with sepsis.

question: म्हाका सॅप्टा झायडम अँटीबायोटिक घेवपाची गरज आसा काय?
answer: तुमी 'चड' मानसिक रगत येवपाच्या संक्रमणा खातीर सेप्टाझायडाम घेतात. ही येवजण 7-10 दीस चालू रावतली.

question: रिविराक्साबान 6 म्हयने कित्याक दितात?
answer: हें प्रिस्क्रिप्शन 'गोथी थ्रोम्बोसिस' (रगत गोठप) खातीर आसा जें तुमी 'सजन खिन' हातूंत पळयलें. प्रिस्क्रिप्शन आसा 'रॅक्सोबन 20 मिलीग्राम/दीस... 6 म्हयन्यां खातीर'.

question: म्हज्या बायलेक फिजिओथॅरपिस्टाकडेन वचपाक जाय काय?
answer: तुवें तुजे कुडीची खास देखरेख करपाची गरज आसा कारण तुवें तें तुज्या सी.ए.आर. फिजिओथेरपी सत्रांनी इबाडयलां.

question: What is the cure for scabies?
answer: "तुरिजीक 17 एप्रिलाक आयव्हरमेक्टिनाची उपचार केल्ली, आनी 7 दिसांनी परत उपचार करतले" अशें सुंदर विधान वाचपाक मेळटा.

question: काय म्हजो सी.टी. स्कॅन पळयलो काय?
answer: तकलेच्या संगणकीय टोमोग्राफींत कसलेच म्हत्वाचे बदल मेळ्ळे नात. हड्ड्याच्या संगणकीय टोमोग्राफींत कसलीच संसर्गजन्य प्रक्रिया सोदून काडली ना.

question: जेन्ना हांव हॉस्पिटलांतल्यान भायर सरलों तेन्ना हांवें कितें केलें?
answer: थोडक्यांत सांगचें जाल्यार, तो "सामान्य स्थितींत", "उदकाचो थर आशिल्लो", आनी "जोर नाशिल्लो" अशें म्हण्टाले. ताची भलायकी सुचोवण्यो "सामान्य" आशिल्ल्यो, आनी तो "सहकार्य करतालो."

discharge_summary: admission: 02/06/2020, discharge: 12/06/2020, stay: 09 d 10 h, location: ward, payer: sus. discharge report [person], 31 years old, born and raised in [address], married, {omitted} at [organization]. date of admission to emergency unit 02/06, hospitalization summary: patient with no known comorbidities or addictions, with severe dry cough, pain in the left hemithorax and decline in general condition that started on 05/20, progressively worsening. sought medical help at the emergency care unit on 01/05 and 02/05 and was released with symptoms. due to persistent complaints, sought consultation with [person], when desaturation and signs of cor pulmonale were evidenced upon pocus according to information from [person]. The patient was referred to our service in poor general condition, hypotensive, with respiratory failure and using a 15 l/min non-rebreathing mask. Orotracheal intubation and intensive care were performed. Pulmonary thromboembolism was ruled out and bilateral pulmonary opacities suggestive of an infectious process were identified. Ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and clarithromycin were started on 6/3 and transitioned to piperacillin, tazobactam, and vancomycin on 6/5 due to septic shock, maintained until 6/12. Vasoactive drugs and neuromuscular blockade were maintained until 6/4. Sedation was discontinued on 6/7, when he was extubated without complications. The patient showed significant clinical, laboratory, and radiological improvements. He was discharged from hospital on 6/12, with guidance on warning signs and symptoms, prescription of symptomatic medications, and referral for follow-up at a primary health care unit. cultures: 04/06 negative urine culture 05/06/23 negative blood culture ongoing antibiotic therapy: ceftriaxone 03/06 to 05/06 clindamycin 03/06 to 05/06 clarithromycin 03/06 to 05/06 piperacillin tazobactam 05/06 to 12/06 vancomycin 05/06 to 12/06 previous devices: orotracheal tube 03 to 07/06 central venous catheter left internal jugular vein 03 to 11/06 intensive care unit: vasoactive drug 03 to 04/06 orotracheal intubation 03 to 07/06 neuromuscular blocker 03 to 04/06 sedation 03 to 07/06 personal history: denies known comorbidities denies known allergies habits: social drinker denies smoking denies drug use of illicit drugs medications in continuous use: ø. complementary exams: chest tomography 03/06 without images of pulmonary artery filling failure. bilateral consolidative opacities with air bronchograms and angiograms between pleural cavities: without effusions or thickening. warning signs and symptoms: intense pain high fever shortness of breath, rapid breathing, shortness of breath, fatigue intense cough with phlegm guidelines after discharge: follow-up in [organization], where to consider a new chest tomography for follow-up vaccination update symptomatic medications if necessary.
question: कितें, म्हाका आतां हॉस्पिटलांत घालतात काय?
answer: तुमी "खर दूख घुंवपी, फाटल्या हॅमटोरॅक्सांत दूख आनी सामान्य स्थिती अशक्तताय" आशिल्ले. तुमी "खराब सामान्य स्थिती, उणो रक्तदाब, स्वास सोडपाक अपेस" पळयिल्लें.

10/04/2022, discharge: 11/04/2022, stay: 01 m 23 h, location: ward, payer: sus. case report: refractory multiple myeloma iga lambda a vi vcd iss without b2mgb/ds iiia diagnosis {omitted} relapse: anemia elevated iga and lambda pleural effusion with cytology 41% atypical plasma cells extramedullary plasmacytoma abdomen and pleura pleural biopsy 04/22: cells with scant eosinophilic cytoplasm and multiple myeloma. abdominal biopsy 04/22: plasma cells infiltrating skeletal muscle tissue. frequent mitotic figures. no necrosis. ihq: cd138, cd56, lambda, kappa. pmo 04/16/21: diluted in sp. sv hypocellular. sb normocellular with preserved maturation. sm megakaryocytes absent in smear bmo 04/16: 35% cellularity. no neoplastic infiltration in the sample. tomography myeloma protocol 02/15/2022: awaiting report transthoracic echocardiography 04/22: ejection fraction 65% mild tricuspid regurgitation, psap 47. 2020 serologies: negative ecog: 1 previous chemotherapies: i vtd pace 07/31/2020 vi vtd d1 10/07/2020 to d1 03/10/2021 while awaiting krd disease progression previous therapeutic schedule krd total of xviii cycles [person]: performed v cycles, with disease progression emergence of plasmacytomas new treatment schedule, as discussed with [person] on 10/23: performance of mcbad for 2 to 2 cycles, while defining a new therapy. d1 i mcbad 09/24. examinations carried out during hospitalization: head tomography 05/10 done in the context of lowered level of consciousness, thrombocytopenia, bleeding ruled out. transthoracic echocardiography 10/08: preserved LVSD subjective s 8 pp 8 LVDD 45 it mild psap 50 mmhg rectification of the septum in the shape of a d extracardiac structure compressing the left atrium moderately depressed RVSD fac 20% transthoracic echocardiography 10/19: fe 62% LVDD 46 s 9.5 pp 9 filamentous images adhered to the atrial face measuring the largest 4 mm suggestive of mild IM vegetation, cultures: blood culture 10/04: staphylococcus mitis 2 samples blood culture 10/08: candida tropicalis sensitive to ketoconazole and amphotericin B micafungin and caspofungin not tested, blood culture 10/12: staphylococcus epidermidis 1 sample after 43 hours considered as a contaminant, antibiotic therapy used: cefepime: 10/04 10/05. escalated to 11/05 due to growth of streptococcus mittis in blood culture on 11/04 meropenem 10/05 10/20 vancomycin 10/05 11/03 micafungin 10/10 evaluation of other specialties: in medical records. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. I prescribe SLOK K 1 tablet every 12 hours. Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. I leave pending tests to monitor eosinophilia and GGT changes, atrial fibrillation that, together with the rash presented after vancomycin on 10/31, raised the diagnostic hypothesis of DRESS syndrome by the dermatologist. Despite this hypothesis, [person] showed complete improvement of the rash and a decrease in the eosinophil count. Therefore, we opted for discharge due to low clinical suspicion at the time. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward and, from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.
question: In my mother's culture, was there any disease found?
answer: 'स्टाफिलोकोकस ओरियस' (एक बॅक्टेरिया) मेळ्ळो 'तारीख १०/०४' ह्या दिसा. 'कॅन्डिडा ट्रोपिकॅलिस' (एक फंगस) मेळ्ळो 'तारीख १०/०८' ह्या दिसा.

question: 19 ऑक्टोबर दिसा केल्ल्या लिव्हर टेस्टाचो (इकोकार्डियोग्राम) निकाल कितें आशिल्लो?
answer: 19 ऑक्टोबर दिसा, ट्रान्ससोफेजल इकोकार्डियोग्राफींत माइट्रल वाल्व्ह प्रोलॅप्स वाडिल्लो दिसलो, जो संसर्गाचो संकेत दितालो (फिलामेंट इमेजिंग), जाका लागून बॅक्टेरिया आनी बुरशीक लागून एंडोकार्डिटिसाच्या विभेदक निदानाची शक्यताय वाडटा.

question: हांवें चेक इन केल्ल्या दुसऱ्या दिसा, म्हळ्यार 5 ऑक्टोबर दिसा, हांव भियेल्लो.
answer: 10 मे दिसा, सेप्टीक शॉक आनी शिरांतल्यान वखदां आनी मुखेल अवयव निकामी जाल्ल्यान ताका हॉस्पिटलांत दाखल केलो आनी 12 मे मेरेन हॉस्पिटलांत दवरलो.

question: कितें, म्हाका खरेंच नांवाचें नवें वखद घेवपाक जाय?
answer: दोतोरांनी सेलिन उदकाची पावसाची परत शिफारस केली आनी 6 सप्तकां उपरांत मेस्टिनिया ग्रीव्हस सेलिन उदकाची पावसाची अनिश्चित काळा खातीर चालू दवरपाची येवजण केली.

question: आनीक काळजाची तपासणी करपाची गरज आसा काय?
answer: हांव 24 तारखेक ट्रान्सफॉरल इकोकार्डियम करतां. 6 सप्तकां फिंग काडपाच्या उपचारा उपरांत परत इकोकार्डियम करपाचो विचार आसा.

Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. I leave pending tests to monitor eosinophilia and GGT changes, atrial fibrillation that, together with the rash presented after vancomycin on 10/31, raised the diagnostic hypothesis of DRESS syndrome by the dermatologist. Despite this hypothesis, [person] showed complete improvement of the rash and a decrease in the eosinophil count. Therefore, we opted for discharge due to low clinical suspicion at the time. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

discharge_summary: admission: 09/01/2020, discharge: 09/17/2020, stay: 16 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: SUS. A 67-year-old patient with a history of overweight, smoking, and major depression was admitted on 09/01 with a perforative acute abdomen, diagnosed after examinations. On the evening of 08/31, she sought care with abdominal pain, general malaise, and dyspnea. She had undergone hysterectomy on 08/30. On 09/01, she underwent exploratory laparotomy with a finding of intestinal perforation, with a suture of the lesion and placement of a peritoneostomy. She developed severe circulatory shock, probably due to peritonitis from contamination of the abdominal cavity, and antibiotic treatment was promptly started. She was re-addressed on 09/06, where an appendectomy and abdominal wall closure were performed. On 09/07, the patient's ventilatory status began to worsen, and a chest tomography scan was performed on 09/08, revealing low-load pulmonary embolism (5%) in addition to pneumonia. A multiresistant germ was isolated in a lung culture, with specific treatment directed at the patient. Given the clinical progression, a tracheostomy was indicated due to the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. On 09/15, {omitted} prolonged cardiopulmonary arrest was reversed after approximately 20 minutes. The patient follow-up appointmented to the intensive care unit after the procedure, with mydriatic pupils and absence of reflexes. On 09/17, a computed tomography scan of the skull was performed, revealing anoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Tests were performed to confirm brain death, which was confirmed on {omitted}. Perforating acute abdomen. 09/01: computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis: pneumoperitoneum, ascites, signs of peritonitis, parietal hyperalces and edema of the loops 09/01: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly, bilateral pleural effusion, opacities suggestive of an inflammatory or infectious process 09/08: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary thromboembolism with 5% embolic burden 09/17: computed tomography of the skull. 09/01: exploratory laparotomy, sigmoid suture, creation of peritoneostomy 09/06: review, touch-ups on previous surgery with appendectomy and closure of the abdominal wall 09/15: tracheostomy 09/15: bilateral chest drainage. death.
question: कितें, म्हाका आतां हॉस्पिटलांत घालतात काय?
answer: तुमी 31/08/2019 दिसा 'कंबरदुखी, सामान्य ताप, आनी श्वास घेवपाक त्रास जाल्ल्यान' दाखल जाल्लें, आनी 01/09/2019 दिसा 'तापान संबंदीत कंबरदुखी खातीर'.
